article_html:
When Rowenna Davis was selected as the Labour candidate for Southampton Itchen nearly two years ago, she started with an experiment. Davis, a 30-year-old former journalist, wanted to see whether traditional Tory voters could be won over by the personal touch, and so she wrote to 300 of them – by hand. “I was asking if they’d meet me or have a conversation with me and whether they’d maybe change their voting intention, and then we called them all afterwards,” she says. There’s a pause. “Very little switch. Very little switch. I’ve still got the blisters.”

Still, that’s the virtue of a two-year campaign – during which Davis has been an unpaid, full-time candidate, who survives, as she puts it, on “debt and generosity.” It gives you time to try things. She and her team have turned this highly marginal constituency – which went to her retiring predecessor John Denham by just 192 votes last time around, and which has been seen as the Conservatives’ best hope of taking a seat off Labour – into a giant laboratory. They test different approaches across the seven wards that make up the seat, comparing test against control, and they persevere with the ones that work – and ditch the ones that don’t.

Related: Ed Miliband: this is a clash of values, not a clash of nations

Davis is one of those natural enthusiasts whose energy is liable to make the rest of us want to crawl back to bed and watch a boxset. As she strides from door to door in Weston, a traditionally Labour area that has been left vulnerable to Ukip by the decline of ship-building in the city, she runs through her strategy with steely precision. “We found a win number, a certain number of promises to vote Labour, and we decided that the way we were going to do it was to look at every single space in the election: the digital space, the doorknocking space, the campaigning space – and to win all of them. To occupy all the spaces. And to win them. So the local paper was a space. Contest it. Occupy it. Do more than your opponent. And do it better.”

To occupy the doorknocking space, the Davis campaign is meeting with 3,000 voters a week, dispatching volunteers to the right doorsteps with an ingenious battery of data analysis tools with strange names like Contact Creator and NationBuilder.

“I’ve started to communicate only in code,” she says, referring to the cryptic three-letter shorthand for a voter’s answers to three crucial questions that provide their profile – will you be voting Labour, did you vote Labour last time, and would you prefer a Labour government. “She’s a DLY! She’s an XBA!”

And, if the polls are right, it’s working: from a 34-34 dead heat in August last year, a survey by Lord Ashcroft in March found Labour now held an eight-point lead.

If Labour emerges as the largest party from the election next week, some say the decisive factor won’t be the “air war” of policy and personality – it will be this “ground war”, which Ed Miliband referred to on Thursday when he proclaimed the “four million conversations” that party activists had held with voters so far. For Frank Spring, a US political consultant who has flown in to help Davis and has something of that American campaign stardust about him, “it is all a matter of what universe you are trying to pull.” Translation: finding the right people to speak to. And it’s an area in which Labour believes it has an advantage.

Related: The Guardian view: Britain needs a new direction, Britain needs Labour | Editorial

“It’s been an evolution,” says one Labour strategist. “At the last election, we saved a load of seats where we had higher contact rates with voters than the Tories because of that marginal difference. The Conservatives don’t really have the local activists who can go out and have those conversations.” But that’s not just about boots on the ground, he adds: “Digital tools like NationBuilder enable better organising in a way that is a qualitative improvement on where we were. Because they’re commercially available to anyone who wants to start a campaign, they massively lower the barrier for entry to that kind of activity. You can do things that wouldn’t have been possible.”

Conservatives don’t put it quite like that, but they concede that their formidable financial lead is somewhat countered by Labour’s campaign machine. “There’s no doubt that we have some work to do on mobilisation,” concedes an insider. “They aren’t going to win, but if they do it certainly won’t be down to Miliband.”

Stella Creasy, the MP for Walthamstow who has a reputation as something of a pioneer in this territory, agrees. “Ed Miliband won’t win or lose it. What Labour activists have been doing for the last two and a half or three years, that’s the reason we can win.” She is so convinced of the value of a sturdy online component that she has built her own bespoke system, called Network Maker, that she believes suits her constituency better than the off-the-peg options. But she is reticent about the details of its advantages, noting: “None of these systems would work if you didn’t have the people, if you weren’t engaging with people. It’s not a silver bullet.”

For most Labour candidates, the online apparatus is divided into two key components: Contact Creator, which is used to keep records of potential voters and ensure that attempts to reach them are well co-ordinated; and NationBuilder, which is primarily used to organise and mobilise volunteers. The former is an in-house creation, the latter bought from a US firm founded by Mark Zuckerberg’s former Harvard room-mate Joe Green, and also used by other parties – although not the Conservatives, for the most part. Romantically associated with the Obama campaign, it really proved its worth on a success story that will appeal less to Labour ears: the SNP’s surprise victory in the 2011 Holyrood elections.

Related: Will Self: Oscar Wilde, champagne socialism and why I’m voting Labour

A visit to Davis’ campaign website demonstrates the depth of engagement that NationBuilder allows. A large panel on the front page asks “will you stand with me?” and enables potential supporters to sign up within a few moments. New additions are added to an internal social network that allows them to join canvassing sessions, connect with the campaign and other volunteers, and tell their friends, all of which will help them earn “political capital” and move up an internal leaderboard that is, unsurprisingly, topped by Davis herself. Visit her Conservative opponent Royston Smith’s site, in contrast, and the only interactive element is a “donations welcome” button that leads to a generic PayPal site.

As leader of the local council’s Conservative group and a lifelong local, Smith has a significant headstart over Davis, who was parachuted in from London two years ago. But while Davis says that she respects him, she is withering about the Conservative campaign. “They couldn’t use NationBuilder,” she says. “They haven’t got the people to co-ordinate. And in an election where people don’t trust the media but do trust their neighbours, that’s a problem.”

Back in Weston, Davis knocks on another door. “Hello, Mrs King,” she says. “I’m Rowenna Davis, I’m standing to be your Labour MP, it’s nice to meet you. You’ve probably known John Denham over the years.” Mrs King makes a sceptical noise. “Not so sure?” She shakes her head. “Well,” Davis ploughs on, dauntless, “you’ll be pleased to hear he’s retiring, then.”

“She is no way going down as a Labour voter,” Davis says, as she heads to the next name on her list. “But when she puts that cross in the box, she won’t have heard from the Conservatives round here. The only person who would have bothered is Labour, and I think that does make a difference.”
